text: Azim yes how does this doesn't matter if
if Free Will exists or if we just
believe it exists yeah so that's the
question that I've been thinking about
for the past few years you know when I
told people that I was doing this panel
every time I told somebody I was doing
this panel the very first question was
oh well does free will exist in every
time I dodged the question and I'm gonna
dodge the question throughout this
session I'm gonna I'm gonna address your
question does it matter what happens if
everybody believes Kristof that we don't
have free will and we live in a world
where unbelief in free will reign
supreme and that effects our behaviors
and thoughts is it going to affect them
in other words what does a world a post
free will belief world look like and I
think it's an important question because
scientific ideas like this one have a
tendency to percolate out into public
consciousness and then affect how people
act and treat each other and a lot of
theorists have worried about this
particular one because they worry that
if we don't believe in free will that's
gonna lead to some sort of moral
breakdown that free will goes and then
moral accountability goes and then we
descend into some lawless dystopia
alternatively there's a number of other
theorists who are more optimistic about
this which is that no it's not gonna
lead to this dystopia instead if we give
up the idea of free will we're also
gonna give up our often destructive
attachments to concepts like ambition
and retribution and so what a number of
my social psychology colleagues and I
have been testing is we've brought
people into the lab and experimentally
manipulated their freewill beliefs which
sounds really sinister but really what
it is is it's just bringing people in
and exposing them to these types of
arguments that freewill does not exist
and then measuring their behavior and so
one of the earliest studies on this was
done by Kathleen Vaz and Jonathan
schooler and what they showed is well if
people are disabused if that idea of
free will if they're told freewill does
not exist then compared to a group whose
freewill beliefs were disturbed
whether they were gonna cheat more and
they did this by giving them a math test
and a math test that was really annoying
and it made you really tempted to cheat
on the test and what they found is that
the people who are told that free will
doesn't exist
they showed much higher rates of
cheating and the the less you believed
in free free will the more you ended up
cheating and a second study looked
instead of cheating it looked at
stealing and you found the same thing so
people who were told that free will
doesn't exist
they stole more from the experiment a
third study which was done by other
researchers looked at aggression so if
it's the same thing if you feel like
you're not morally accountable for your
actions then why don't you aggress
against somebody that you don't like and
social psychologists have this kind of
strange way of measuring aggression in
the lab we can't bring participants in
and actually have them hurt each other
in any serious way and so what we do is
we we bring two participants in and we
make them dislike each other and then we
give one of them the opportunity to
spike the other ones food with hot sauce
and they know that the other person does
not like spicy food so in this case hot
sauce is used as a weapon of aggression
and as you would expect at this point
the the people who were told that free
will doesn't exist they used about twice
as much hot sauce so they they really
gave in to their desires to aggress in
this case because why not now those
experiments they give some credence to
these these dystopian fears that maybe
we're gonna see a moral breakdown but
there are some other arguably positive
benefits and these are particularly in
the realm of punishment right so if
holding yourself less morally
responsible for your actions leads us to
engage in moral behavior well maybe then
holding other people less morally
responsible is going to reduce our
emphasis on retribution on the type of
punishment where we're just looking to
make other people suffer for the
transgressions that they've caused and
maybe it'll make us focus more on the
punishment that actually has a social
benefit that has a utilitarian advantage
in terms of making people deterring
other people from committing crimes or
rehabilitating people
you
